awd_titl_txt: IntroCS POGIL: Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning in Introductory Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The significance of the proposed project is that it will establish the value of Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL) as an approach to teaching computer science.  The POGIL approach has been shown in other STEM disciplines to increase student learning and retention, particularly for students from underrepresented populations, including females and minorities. There has not yet been a concerted effort to teach computer science using the POGIL approach. The creation of a computer science POGIL community, which is a fundamental aspect of this proposal, is a necessary step to providing an evaluation of the effectiveness of POGIL in computer science education. Broader and more effective use of strategies such as POGIL will improve the quality, quantity, and diversity of students who complete STEM programs.

The main goal of this project is to study factors that most influence faculty to adopt POGIL in introductory computer science courses and how the degree of POGIL implementation impacts student learning and engagement. A secondary goal is to make it significantly easier for computer science faculty to adopt POGIL, by disseminating high quality instructional resources and enhancing current professional development practices. The project theory of action is that enhanced instructor support will improve faculty adoption of and persistence with POGIL, which in turn will improve student outcomes. To assess the impact of these and other factors, the project will collect and analyze multi-institutional data including surveys, interviews, and student learning outcomes.

por.por_cntn:
From 2017 - 2022, the IntroCS POGIL project supported college faculty of introductory computer science (IntroCS) courses in their adoption of Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL). POGIL is a research-based instructional strategy in which self-managed teams of students simultaneously construct understanding and develop process skills such as teamwork, problem solving, and critical thinking.

The main two goals of our project were (1) to study the adoption and implementation of POGIL in IntroCS courses, and (2) to make adoption significantly easier for faculty by disseminating high-quality instructional resources and enhancing professional development practices. Our project created two professional development programs: one that trained faculty to teach effectively using POGIL, and one that trained faculty to author POGIL classroom activities.

The broader impacts of the project included:

  • 50 Faculty from 38 institutions trained as POGIL instructors
  • 31 Faculty from 23 institutions trained as POGIL authors
  • 70 IntroCS Activities Disseminated
  • 58 New Classroom Activities Written
  • 13 Faculty Mentors
  • 5,000+ Students

Presentations and publications:

  • 16 3- to 6-Hour Workshops
  • 8 Conference Special Sessions
  • 5 Conference Papers
  • 2 Magazine Articles
  • 2 Book Chapters

The Activity Writing Program supported 31 faculty participants as authors, resulting in 58 original CS classroom activities that were published via the POGIL Activity Clearinghouse and available to any instructor under a Creative Commons license. Each activity underwent a rigorous review process, including six stages of writing, feedback, and revision. 5 writing mentors and 11 non-CS faculty (POGIL experts) participated as reviewers for pedagogical design, and 11 CS faculty (content experts) participated as reviewers for technical correctness. The national POGIL Project and POGIL Activity Clearinghouse are adopting many of our programs.

Throughout the project, we collected a large amount of multi-institutional data from faculty and students. The faculty data included interview transcripts (pre and post training), a survey on POGIL how they used POGIL, reflections on teaching, and grade distributions. The student data included a survey on sense of belonging, a survey on teamwork perception, and an in-class learning assessment.

Our project contributed new knowledge to answer the research questions: (1) What factors influence faculty to adopt POGIL in IntroCS courses? (2) How does POGIL influence faculty perceptions of student learning and engagement? (3) How does POGIL influence student perceptions of their own learning and engagement? (4) How does POGIL influence student learning in IntroCS courses?

Our most significant research findings:

  • Students taught with POGIL outperformed students in other sections. POGIL students scored higher on a post-test, and a higher proportion of them met the grade requirement to progress to the next course. After a five-week winter break, POGIL students had higher and more consistent scores on a retention test.
  • Students working in POGIL teams performed better on quizzes and programming assignments than students working individually on the same POGIL activities. 
  • Faculty adopting POGIL in IntroCS courses can expect to see a modest increase of A grades and a modest decrease of DFW grades over time.
  • Faculty motivations to use POGIL centered around improving student outcomes, including learning and engagement. However, faculty also had concerns, which ranged from how POGIL impacts the curriculum to logistical and institutional barriers.

Selected references:

A Five Stage Faculty Development Program to Transform Introductory Courses in Computer Science: The IntroCS POGIL Project. C. Kussmaul, H. H. Hu, C. Mayfield, and P. B. Campbell. 2023. In Handbook of STEM Faculty Development. Information Age Publishing: Charlotte, NC.

Teamwork in CS1: Student Learning and Experience with POGIL. H. H. Hu, A. Yadav, D. M. Gavin, C. Kussmaul, C. Mayfield. SIGCSE 2023.

POGIL in CS1: Evidence for Student Learning and Belonging. C. Mayfield, S. Moudgalya, A. Yadav, C. Kussmaul, H. H. Hu. SIGCSE 2022.

Professional Development and Support for POGIL in Computer Science. C. Kussmaul, H. H. Hu, P. B. Campbell, C. Mayfield, A. Yadav. SIGCSE 2022.

Measuring Students? Sense of Belonging in Introductory CS Courses. S. Moudgalya, C. Mayfield, A. Yadav, H. H. Hu, C. Kussmaul. SIGCSE 2021.

Collaborative Learning, Self-Efficacy, and Student Performance in CS1 POGIL. A. Yadav, C. Mayfield, S. Moudgalya, C. Kussmaul, H. H. Hu. SIGCSE 2021.
